sen.j: 多田氏（ただし）は、清和源氏の流れを汲む一族。
sen.e: Tada clan was the descendants of "Seiwa-Genji" (Minamoto clan).
The Tada clan were the descendants of "Seiwa-Genji" (Minamoto clan).
The Tada clan were the descendants of "Seiwa-Genji" (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: 摂津国川辺郡多田より発祥。
sen.e: The family name "Tada" originated from the place name of Tada, Kawabe-gun, Settsu Province (today's eastern part of Hyogo Prefecture).
The family name "Tada" originated from the place name of Tada, Kawabe-gun, Settsu Province (in the eastern part of which is now Hyogo Prefecture).
The family name "Tada" originated from the place name of Tada, Kawabe County, Settsu Province (in the eastern part of which is now Hyogo Prefecture).
The family crest was, for example, the figure of a lion and a peony.
The family crest was, for example, the figures of a lion and peony.
The family crest was, for example, the figures of a lion and peony.

sen.j: 平安時代中期に摂津国川辺郡多田の地に武士団を形成した源満仲が「多田」を号したことから始まる。
sen.e: "Tada" began to be used by MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who formed a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe-gun, Settsu Province, in the middle of the Heian period.
"Tada" began to be used by MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who formed a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe-gun, Settsu Province, in the middle of the Heian period.
Tada began to be used by MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, who formed a samurai group in Tada, Kawabe County Settsu Province, in the middle of the Heian period.

sen.j: その後、多田の地は満仲の長子であった源頼光とその子・源頼国が継承し、頼国の五男・源頼綱以降、嫡流が「多田」を号した。
sen.e: Afterward, the real estate in Tada was inherited by MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu (the oldest son of Mitsunaka), and then by MINAMOTO no Yorikuni (the son of Yorimitsu), and from MINAMOTO no Yoritsuna (the fifth son of Yorikuni), the lineage of the oldest son succeeded to the family name of "Tada."

Afterward, the real estate in Tada was inherited by MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu (the eldest son of Mitsunaka), and then by MINAMOTO no Yorikuni (the son of Yorimitsu), and from MINAMOTO no Yoritsuna (the fifth son of Yorikuni) the lineage of the eldest son succeeded to the family name of "Tada."

Afterward, the real estate in Tada was inherited by MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu (the eldest son of Mitsunaka), and then by MINAMOTO no Yorikuni (the son of Yorimitsu), and from MINAMOTO no Yoritsuna (the fifth son of Yorikuni) the lineage of the eldest son succeeded to the family name of 'Tada.'

sen.j: 頼綱以降では馬場氏族や山県氏族といった庶流を輩出しており、多田氏の系統は清和源氏一族の最も古い所領である多田の地を200年余りに渡って相続した。
sen.e: After Yoritsuna, the lineage of Tada clan produced the collateral branches, such as Baba clan and Yamagata clan, and the lineage inherited over 200-odd years the real estate in Tada, which was the oldest territory of all owned by Seiwa-Genji.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After Yoritsuna, the lineage of the Tada clan produced collateral branches, such as the Baba and Yamagata clans, and over of more than 200 years the lineage inherited the real estate in Tada, which was the oldest territory of all owned by Seiwa-Genji.

After Yoritsuna, the lineage of the Tada clan produced collateral branches, such as the Baba and Yamagata clans, and over of more than 200 years the lineage inherited the real estate in Tada, which was the oldest territory of all owned by Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan).

sen.j: が、治承・寿永の乱に嫡流であった多田行綱が源頼朝に疎まれ多田荘の所領を没収されると衰退し、以後一族の動向を伝える史料は断片的なものとなっている（多田源氏の項目も参照）。
sen.e: However, the lineage went into decline when Yukitsuna TADA, who belonged to the clan's lineage of the oldest son, was shunned and deprived of the real estate in Tada during Jisho-Juei War by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and thereafter historical materials making mention of what happened to the clan became fragmentary (cf. the article of "Tada-Genji").
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the lineage went into decline when Yukitsuna TADA, who belonged to the clan's lineage of the eldest son, was shunned and deprived of the real estate in Tada during the Jisho-Juei War by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and thereafter the historical materials making mention of what happened to the clan became fragmentary (see the article of "Tada-Genji").

However, the lineage went into decline when Yukitsuna TADA, who belonged to the clan's lineage of the eldest son, was shunned and deprived of the real estate in Tada during the Jisho-Juei War by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, and thereafter the historical materials making mention of what happened to the clan became fragmentary (see the article of "Tada-Genji").

sen.j: 多田氏の衰退後、『群書類従』収録の「多田系図」などによると源兼綱の子である源頼兼（『尊卑分脈』では源頼政の次男とされる）が多田氏を再興した。
sen.e: Tada clan, after going into decline, was revived by MINAMOTO no Yorikane, who was, "Tada clan's genealogy" on "Gunsho Ruiju" (Collection of historical documents compiled by Hokiichi HANAWA) says, the son of MINAMOTO no Kanetsuna - or "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy) says the second son of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Tada clan, following its decline, was revived by MINAMOTO no Yorikane, who was the "Tada clan's genealogy" according to "Gunsho Ruiju" (a collection of historical documents compiled by Hokiichi HANAWA), the son of MINAMOTO no Kanetsuna; however, "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy) states the second son of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa.

The Tada clan, following its decline, was revived by MINAMOTO no Yorikane, who was the son of MINAMOTO no Kanetsuna according to the 'Tada clan's genealogy' in "Gunsho Ruiju" (a collection of historical documents compiled by Hokiichi HANAWA); however, "Sonpi Bunmyaku" (a text compiled in the 14th century that records the lineages of the aristocracy) states the second son of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa.

sen.j: 頼兼は伊豆国を地盤として鎌倉幕府とも繋がりを持ったとされる。
sen.e: Putting its foothold in Izu Province (part of today's Shizuoka Prefecture), Yorikane is said to have linked with Kamakura "bakufu" (Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Gaining a foothold in Izu Province (part of today's Shizuoka Prefecture), Yorikane is said to have linked with the Kamakura "bakufu" (a Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun).
Gaining a foothold in Izu Province (part of today's Shizuoka Prefecture), Yorikane is said to have linked with the Kamakura "bakufu" (a Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: この流れを伊豆多田氏と呼び、室町期には摂津と伊豆に領土を安堵されるが、永正年間（1504年 - 1520年）の将軍家家督争いで足利義稙側に付き没落したという。
sen.e: This lineage, called Izu-Tada clan, was authorized to own its lands in Settsu and Izu Province during the Muromachi period, and the clan is said to have been in decline in the Eisho era (A.D. 1504 - 1520) because it took the side of Yoshitane ASHIKAGA in the midst of the succession dispute over the shogunate.

This lineage, referred to as the Izu-Tada clan, was authorized to own its lands in the Settsu and Izu provinces during the Muromachi period but is said to have been in decline in the Eisho era (A.D. 1504 - 1520) because it took the side of Yoshitane ASHIKAGA in the midst of the dispute over succession to the shogunate.

This lineage, referred to as the Izu-Tada clan, was authorized to own its lands in the Settsu and Izu provinces during the Muromachi period but is said to have been in decline in the Eisho era (A.D. 1504 - 1520) because it took the side of Yoshitane ASHIKAGA in the midst of the dispute over succession to the shogunate.

sen.j: しかし、この伊豆多田氏については系譜や事跡に不明な点が多く実像がはっきりしていない。
sen.e: What Izu-Tada clan was really like is unclear, since there exist many points yet to be known about its lineage and historical facts.
It is somewhat unclear what the Izu-Tada clan was really like, since many points are yet to be known about its lineage and historical facts.
It is somewhat unclear what the Izu-Tada clan was really like, since many points are yet to be known about its lineage and historical facts.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代初期の多田経実に始まり大和国の国人（衆徒）として存続した多田氏は源満仲の後裔と伝え代々佐比山城に拠ったが、別族とも取れる記述が見られるなど系譜が明確でない。
sen.e: The Tada clan founded by Tsunezane TADA in the early Kamakura period existed in Yamato Province (today's Nara Prefecture) as local samurai, and this clan, which is said to have been the descendants of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, put its foothold at Sahiyama-jo Castle for generations, but in some historical sources there exist some depictions which can be taken as the meaning that this lineage had nothing to do with Tada clan mentioned above, so the detail of this lineage is unclear.

The Tada clan, as founded by Tsunezane TADA in the early Kamakura period, existed in Yamato Province (today's Nara Prefecture) as local samurai, and this clan, which is said to have comprised descendants of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, maintained a foothold at Sahiyama-jo Castle for generations; however, in some historical sources there are depictions that can be taken to mean that this lineage had nothing to do with the Tada clan mentioned above, so the detail of this lineage is unclear.

The Tada clan, as founded by Tsunezane TADA in the early Kamakura period, existed in Yamato Province (today's Nara Prefecture) as local samurai, and this clan, which is said to have comprised descendants of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, maintained a foothold at Sahiyama-jo Castle for generations; however, in some historical sources there are depictions that can be taken to mean that this lineage had nothing to do with the Tada clan mentioned above, so the detail of this lineage is unclear.

sen.j: また、大江広元の舅であった多田仁綱が摂津源氏多田氏の出身と伝え、仁綱の娘は広元との間に大江親広（寒河江氏の祖）を儲けているが、仁綱の名は『尊卑分脈』等の系図に見えていない。
sen.e: And it is said that Noritsuna TADA, who was the father-in-law of OE no Hiromoto, was from "Settsu-Genji" (Minamoto clan), and that Noritsuna's daughter and Hiromoto had their child OE no Chikahiro (the founder of Sagae clan), but the name of Noritsuna cannot be found in the Tada clan's genealogy on Sonpi Bunmyaku and other historical sources.

It is also said that Noritsuna TADA, who was the father-in-law of OE no Hiromoto, was from "Settsu-Genji" (Minamoto clan), and that Noritsuna's daughter and Hiromoto had their child, OE no Chikahiro (the founder of the Sagae clan), but the Noritsuna name can't be found in the Tada clan's genealogy on Sonpi Bunmyaku and other historical sources.

It is also said that Noritsuna TADA, who was the father-in-law of OE no Hiromoto, was from the Tada clan of "Settsu-Genji" (Minamoto clan), and that Noritsuna's daughter and Hiromoto had their child, OE no Chikahiro (the founder of the Sagae clan), but the Noritsuna name can't be found in the Tada clan's genealogy on "Sonpi Bunmyaku" and other historical sources.
sen.cmt: 『』に ""摂津源氏多田氏の「多田氏」訳漏れ対応しました。

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)には、多田頼貞、多田貞綱、多田義基などが南朝 (日本)方の武将として活動しているが、その明確な系譜は未詳である（『尊卑分脈』には多田頼盛の三男能瀬高頼の後裔に頼貞、貞綱の名が見える）。
sen.e: During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, some warlords named Tada, such as Yorisada TADA, Sadatsuna TADA, and Yoshimoto TADA, fought on the side of the Southern Court, but the detail of their family is unlear; incidentally, in Sonpi Bunmyaku, there exists the depiction that Takayori NOSE (the third son of Yorimori TADA) had Yorisada and Sadatsuna as his descendants.

During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, some warlords called Tada, such as Yorisada TADA, Sadatsuna TADA and Yoshimoto TADA, fought on the side of the Southern Court, but the details of their family is unlear; incidentally, in Sonpi Bunmyaku there is the depiction that Takayori NOSE (the third son of Yorimori TADA) had Yorisada and Sadatsuna as his descendants.

During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, some warlords called Tada, such as Yorisada TADA, Sadatsuna TADA and Yoshimoto TADA, fought on the side of the Southern Court, but the details of their family is unlear; incidentally, in "Sonpi Bunmyaku" there is the depiction that Takayori NOSE (the third son of Yorimori TADA) had Yorisada and Sadatsuna as his descendants.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には、源満快の子孫とされる摂津国宿野城の多田氏や、頼光流とする一方で源満季の後裔であるとの説が存在する多田満頼（甲斐多田氏）などが見られる。
sen.e: During the Sengoku period (Period of Warring States), there existed the Tada clan that is said to have been the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsuyoshi, whose foothold was at Shukuno-jo Castle in Settsu Province, and also existed Mitsuyori TADA (a member of Kai-Tada clan), who is commonly said to have fallen under the lineage of Yorimitsu - some say he was the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsusue.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the Sengoku (Warring States) period, there existed the Tada clan that is said to have been the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsuyoshi, whose foothold was at Shukuno-jo Castle in Settsu Province, and there also existed Mitsuyori TADA (a member of the Kai-Tada clan), who is commonly said to have fallen under the lineage of Yorimitsu; some say he was the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsusue.

During the Sengoku (Warring States) period, there existed the Tada clan that is said to have been the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsuyoshi, whose foothold was at Shukuno-jo Castle in Settsu Province, and there also existed Mitsuyori TADA (a member of the Kai-Tada clan), who is commonly said to have fallen under the lineage of Yorimitsu; some say he was the descendant of MINAMOTO no Mitsusue.

sen.j: が、『尊卑分脈』等の系図では満季、満快の後裔に「多田」を号す者は確認できない。
sen.e: On the genealogy of Sonpi Bunmyaku and other historical sources, however, there can be seen no descendant of Mitsusue, nor that of Mitsuyoshi, who called itself Tada clan.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the genealogy of Sonpi Bunmyaku and other historical sources there is no mention of any descendant of Mitsusue, nor that of Mitsuyoshi, called the Tada clan.
However, in the genealogy of "Sonpi Bunmyaku" and other historical sources there is no mention of any descendant of Mitsusue, nor that of Mitsuyoshi, called the Tada clan.

sen.j: その他、加賀一向一揆の大将であった河合宣久（多田政晴）や摂津上津城に拠った多田春正などが多田氏の一族と伝えている。
sen.e: In addition, some figures are said to have belonged to Tada clan, such as Nobuhisa KAWAI (also called Masaharu TADA), who was the boss of an uprising in Kaga Province (today's southern part of Ishikawa Prefecture) made by followers of Ikko sect of Buddhism, and Harumasa TADA, who put his foothold at Uetsu-jo Castle in Settsu Province.

Moreover, some figures are said to have belonged to the Tada clan, such as Nobuhisa KAWAI (also called Masaharu TADA), who was the boss of an uprising in Kaga Province (in the southern part of today's Ishikawa Prefecture) carried out by followers of the Ikko sect of Buddhism, and Harumasa TADA, who had a foothold at Uetsu-jo Castle, in Settsu Province.

Moreover, some figures are said to have belonged to the Tada clan, such as Nobuhisa KAWAI (also called Masaharu TADA), who was the boss of an uprising in Kaga Province (in the southern part of today's Ishikawa Prefecture) carried out by followers of the Ikko sect of Buddhism, and Harumasa TADA, who had a foothold at Uetsu-jo Castle, in Settsu Province.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、甲斐多田氏の一族が旗本に列した。
sen.e: In the Edo period, Kai-Tada clan was ranked "hatamoto" (direct retainers of the 'bakuhu' [the Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun]).
In the Edo period, the Kai-Tada clan was ranked "hatamoto" (direct retainers of the 'bakuhu' [the Japanese feudal regime headed by a shogun]).
In the Edo period, the Kai-Tada clan was ranked "hatamoto" (direct retainers of the 'bakuhu').
